channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Bored of jobs that don't matter? Be a Perl developer and save lives
item.description: This web-app saves lives, and literally pushes forward medical science. Your work will be used by the NHS, research labs, and healthcare providers worldwide to diagnose patients, organize research, and make the world a better place.

item.title: One is the Loneliest Number
item.description: For nearly 16 years, our client has been helping people in the UK and the US find their perfect flatmate. Think of all the things that are better with two: seesaws, tandem bicycles, the tango, splitting the billsâ€”need we go on? If youâ€™re a Perl software developer, and you agree that two heads are better than one, then this might be the role for you.

item.title: A New Way to Work. Perl Job in London
item.description: Our client is looking for a senior-level Perl programmer who believes in innovation. They are one of the UKâ€™s leading estate agencies with over 60 branches and a spectacular web presence that puts others to shame. Leave behind the offices of old and get ready for a tiered lake, decked boardwalk, pathways, events space, and an on-site Virgin Active gym.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge : Week 48
item.description: Please checkout Scimon's thought process dealing with Palindrome date. Highly Recommended.

item.title: PWC 048 â€º Palindrome Dates (mm/dd/yyyy)
item.description: Ryan pointed out February 2, 2020 was a Palindromic date irrespective of data format. Must Read

item.title: PWC 048 â€º Survivor (Josepheus problem)
item.description: Ryan made good use Circular Linked List to solve the task. Must Read.

item.title: My first date with Raku
item.description: I shared my first encounter with Raku as far as the weekly challenge is concerned.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 48: Survivors and Palindrome Dates
item.description: Luca's implementation of Palindrome date is worth reading. I enjoyed it thoroughly.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 48: Survivor and Palindrome Dates
item.description: Laurent shared generic survivor task solution. You won't get bored of reading his blog.

item.title: PERL WEEKLY CHALLENGE â€“ 048
item.description: Javier made use of "push" and "shitf" very elegantly to solve the survivor task.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 048: Survivor and Palindrome Dates
item.description: Choroba shared multiple approach to solve the survivor task. Must Read.

item.title: Surviving Dates with Raku
item.description: Arne's blog is always packed with diagram and detail explanation. Highly Recommended.

item.description: Raku Solutions Review by Ryan Thompson.

item.description: Recap of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: The Perl Community Roadmap
item.description: Will shared his idea of Perl Community Roadman.

item.title: Possibly the best k-means clustering ... in the world!
item.description: Short post this time because I got nerd-sniped looking at the data. The fun part is that you quickly move from thinking about how to get your results to trying to work out what they mean.

item.title: KBOS types
item.description: Following up earlier post about <a href="http://blogs.perl.org/users/lichtkind/2020/02/introducing-kbos.html"Introducing KBOS", Herbert now talking about KBOS type.

item.title: Deprecating or Transferring Mojo::ACME
item.description: Joel shared the reason why he is planning to deprecate Mojo::Acme.

item.title: Perl v5.31.9 Released
item.description: Renee has released Perl 5.31.9, a development release of Perl with support for Unicode 13.0 and updates 19 core modules.

item.title: #448 - What is Cor?
item.description:
Hi there

I have been following very closely the progress of Cor. Well, if you don't know what I am talking about? It is a project that Curtis Poe, Steven Little and Sawyer working on to create an object model for the Perl core. If you are interested to know more about the project then follow the page.

A friend of mine, Andrew Solomon (Geekuni), couple of days ago tweeted about an interesting Survey: which CPAN modules should all Perl developers know? Please do take part in the survey if you fancy.

Have fun rest of the week.
